div1.p: Student of Yellow Fever: Dr. Lazear Really Sacrificed His Life to Science

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Chicago Record, [1900]
div1.p:
Dr. Lazear Really Sacrificed His Life
to Science.

The recent death in Cuba of Dr. Jesse
Lazear, caused by an attack of yellow
fever, furnishes a pathetic and interest-
ing example of one among a limited
few who have really sacrificed them-
selves to science. Sent by the United
States government to investigate more
fully the causes of yellow fever, which
has always been the bane of the West
Indies, Dr. Lazear at once devoted him-
self assiduously to the task before him.
Working early and late in a climate to
which he was entirely unused and
which was swarming with the germs
he was studying, it is not strange that
he himself fell an easy prey to the rav-
ages of the dreaded bacillus.

For many reasons his untimely death
is to be lamented. His superior training
in scientific methods at Johns Hopkins
university and his practical experience
while connected with the clinical labora-
tory of that institution peculiarly fitted
him for the work to which he was call-
ed. Previous to his appointment to
Cuba he had made important original
investigations into the finer structure
of the malarial parasite and into the
cardiac complications which often occur
in certain of the venereal diseases. In
fact, he early gave promise of being a
valuable acquisition to the world of ex-
perimental science which sincerely
mourns his loss.

It may be of interest to mention brief-
ly a few facts concerning the terrible
scourge of those tropic islands, which
Dr. Lazear was sent to investigate. In-
deed, our own country is never immune
from its fearful ravages. The southern
states are particularly susceptible to
epidemic, although, as in 1793 to 1802,
regions as far north as Philadelphia,
Baltimore and Boston suffered severely.
The population of the first named city
in 1793 was but 40,000, yet the mortality
during September and October of that
year was 3,435. In 1852 New Orleans
suffered an epidemic in which the death
list reached 8,000, while the latest ex-
tended one --that of 1878--proved the
most disastrous in history, 16,000 suc-
cumbing in Louisiana, Mississippi and
Alabama alone. During these epidem-
ics negroes were shown to be less sus-
ceptible to the disease than whites, yet
they were far from being entirely im-
mune, statistics showing that the per-
centage of fatality in that race is about
21, as compared to a percentage of 50
in the white race. Successfully with-
standing a single attack of the fever
by one of either race, however, almost
always renders one immune for life.

As to the causes of yellow fever, very
little is known. For many years it has
been suspected by bacteriologists that
it is due to a specific microbe, yet it
has been only within the last few years
that any have attempted to describe it.
Saurelli, the famous Italian investigator
and director of the Institute of Experi-
imental Medicine at Montevideo, re-
cently submitted to the scientific world
a description of the so-called icteriodes
bacillus, which he claimed to have iso-
lated. In his zeal to ascertain the
truth of his theories concerning it, how-
ever, he resorted to experiments which
sadly mar his otherwise brilliant record
as a scientist. He not only introduced
the deadly cultures into the systems of
lower animals, but wantonly subjected
human beings to the same treatment.

He says: “By this method I obtained
all the symptoms of the disease.”
“Such conduct,” adds a recognized au-
thority in medicine, “is nothing short
of criminal and should not be counte-
nanced by the civilized world.” Yet,
notwithstanding these claims of Sau-
relli and similar ones made later by
Sternberg, surgeon general of the
United States army, the medical world
is to-day much in the dark concern this
disease and its specific cause.

In the beginning of an attack of yel-
low fever a slight chill is common, ac-
companied by headache and pains in
the back and limbs. Fever soon comes
on and rises rapidly. The face is
flushed, the tongue furred but moist,
the eyes red, the throat dry. Manifesta-
tions of the progress of the disease now
soon appear. Briefly stated, they are
as follows: The skin becomes yellow,
the patient throws up at frequent inter-
vals quantities of the characteristic
“black vomit” and external hem-
orrhages are of frequent occurrence.
Post-mortem examination usually re-
veals fatty degeneration of the heart
and liver, as well as swelling and in-
flammation of the kidneys. The dura-
tion of an attack is usually short, but
severe, the mortality at various times
ranging between 15 per cent. and 85
per cent.

The treatment of to-day, together
with careful nursing, is almost entirely
symptomatic, such common drugs as
iron and quinine being much in favor.
Bleeding is never practiced as of old.
Benjamin Rush, the famous physician
of 100 years ago, for whom Rush med-
ical college was named, is quoted as
saying: “From a newly arrived Eng-
lishman I took 144 ounces of blood at
12 bleedings in six days. I gave within
the course of the same six days nearly
150 grains of calomel, with the usual
proportions of jalap and camboge.”
Yet this man of heroic treatment and
dosage seems to have been eminently
successful in many cases, as the records
show.

In view of a disease so terrible and
often so far-reaching in its effects,
should not the American people give
honor to whom honor is due by crown-
ing the work of Dr. Lazear as heroic
in the extreme?
